column1: Neck dissection is surgery to remove the lymph nodes in the neck.
Neck dissection is a major surgery done to remove lymph nodes that contain cancer.
- Modified radical neck dissection: This is the most common type of neck dissection.
Cancer cells in the mouth or throat can travel in the lymph fluid and get trapped in the lymph nodes.
Your doctor may recommend this procedure if: - You have cancer of the mouth, tongue, thyroid gland, or other areas of the throat or neck.

Risks for anesthesia and surgery in general are: - Allergic reactions to medicines - Breathing problems - Bleeding - Infection Other risks for this surgery are: - Numbness in the skin and ear on the side of the surgery, which may be permanent - Damage to the nerves of the lip and tongue - Problems lifting the shoulder and arm - Limited neck movement - Drooping shoulder on the side of the surgery - Problems talking or swallowing

- If you have been drinking a lot of alcohol, more than 1 or 2 drinks a day During the days before your surgery: - You may be asked to stop taking aspirin, ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin), naproxen (Aleve, Naprosyn), clopidogrel (Plavix), warfarin (Coumadin), and any other medicines that make it hard for your blood to clot.
